text.section: In this section, "financial institution" has the meaning stated in § 6-201 of this article.
The Treasurer may appoint any financial institution as a fiscal agent.
During its agency, the fiscal agent shall be covered by a surety bond in the form and amount required by law.

section.section: In accordance with the procedures that the Treasurer sets, a fiscal agent shall pay at the financial institution, from money advanced to the agent, the interest on State debt and, as the principal matures, the principal.
The fiscal agent shall keep a receipt for each payment.

text.section:
Each fiscal agent shall:
allow the Treasurer to inspect the agent's accounts at any time; and
provide copies of the accounts on request of:
the Senate;
the House of Delegates;
the Comptroller; or
the Treasurer.

section.section: The Treasurer shall examine, count, and record each State bond and coupon that a fiscal agent returns.

Once every 2 years, after the Legislative Auditor verifies the records of the Treasurer, the Comptroller and the Treasurer or their deputies shall destroy all State bonds and coupons that the fiscal agents returned before the close of the last fiscal year.
The State bonds and coupons shall be destroyed in the presence of the Legislative Auditor or a designee of the Auditor.
The Comptroller, Treasurer, and Legislative Auditor shall execute a certificate that states the total number of State bonds and coupons destroyed and that attests to the destruction of all of them.

text.section:
The Treasurer shall:
keep all certificates of destruction; and
send copies of each certificate to the presiding officers of the General Assembly.

The Treasurer shall:
deposit unredeemed principal and interest into an unpresented bond and coupon account; and
dispose of unredeemed principal and interest as provided in Title 17 of the Commercial Law Article.
